posts.name: marshall
posts.cooked:
Yeah yeah… my post title is click-bait… it’s on purpose.  I can’t let @Ryan_Swanson have all the fun.  We need to talk though and I need your attention.

Sup Chief… it’s your friendly robot network guy here.  You know, the one who helped with writing a paper about how to make robot ethernet more reliable.  The one who has rebooted and flashed these OM5P radios so many times that I built a custom raspbian deployment to make my life easier for it.  The one who told you about the second port being kinda crap… yeah… that guy.

Look… I need you to help me… and by that, I need you to help all of us.  We all want to compete at our best, right?  We are getting ready to go into DCMPs and CMP events and the wireless coverage is about to get worse and the stakes are higher.

So let’s talk about this for a second.

There is a set of ambient field radio conditions, in which one robot in a match can lose its radio link and then all other robots on the field will also lose their links and stop/stutter/disconnect/reconnect.  It’s real.

One robot’s bad radio can take down the other 5. Sometimes it is on disconnect and sometimes it is on reconnect when that radio comes back up.  You can find quite a few matches where this has happened.  I’m not posting any links because I don’t want to call out any teams specifically because that’s not cool… if others want to share them then they can but that’s on them.  The goal here isn’t shaming teams.  It isn’t their fault.

To be really clear - I’m not blaming the teams here but I do think we can all step up and help each other out with this.

The FTAs sometimes use the phrase “Christmas Tree” and sometimes they’ll decide to replay the matches where this happens.  Other times, you get stuck in the question box (it’s definitely not an answer box).  You might have DS logs showing disconnects from 1, 3, 6, 10, or even 12 teams all at once even and you might still get ignored and deferred to “HQ” or told “it’s out of my hands”.  That’s ok… let’s not despair.  It’s not the FTA’s fault.  They didn’t pick these radios or the ambient arena wifi conditions.

Well… I’m here to give you some advice and some hope.  Maybe we can all help each other with this.  Check your alliance partners.  Check the opposing alliance.  Verify that they have a solid main battery connection.  Check their radio power pathway and ensure it is fully connected, seated correctly, and that the radio won’t turn off when they drive over a bump on the field or take an impact under defense.  We have to do this for each other because we can’t rely on Inspectors, FTAs, CSAs, and others to catch it.  They just won’t.  Please make sure your radios stay powered on and connected… if not for your sake then for the sake of the other 5 robots on the field.

You can try reducing your bandwidth usage on the field to below 4 megabits per second and that might help too.

Lastly… turn off your personal wifi and personal wifi hotspots.  It’s likely that all of this is ultimately caused by interference and the radios are doing renegotiation to sort out how to deal with the clients (the robots).  We can’t control the venue wifi but we can control our own.  I’m begging you… please help me out here.  Let’s elevate each other and give each other the best experience we can with these radios being what they are.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
marshall:

Lastly… turn off your personal wifi and personal wifi hotspots.

I assume this means our cellphone telephones?

posts.name: marshall
posts.cooked: Yes.

posts.name: Ryan Swanson
posts.cooked:
marshall:

I can’t let @Ryan_Swanson have all the fun.

It’s an art form. You nailed it.

posts.name: TimO
posts.cooked: Some description of what this means for the non-technical people is needed. At our last qualifier, the FTA made the request (during practice matches) that people in the stands turn off their cell phone wifi. A parent pulled out their phone and said “I’m okay, it’s not connected to anything”.   I had to walk them through the process and try to explain why. I don’t know of a good solution, but some general posting on the video displays or signage along with regular announcements might help. Maybe the FMS could have a honeypot?

posts.name: marshall
posts.cooked:
TimO:

Some description of what this means for the non-technical people is needed.

What I think is happening… and I’m just now digging into the weeds on 5Ghz AC wifi is that one of the clients (a robot) is dropping off and the field Access Point (the field wifi network) is then shuffling the clients around under a new set of conditions to form “optimal” links.  I’ll be honest and say that I’m not an RF guy… I’m a network guy… so I really am trying to explore what the technical reason is for it happening.

As for turning off wifi… you turn it off because even when no one is connected, it is still broadcasting every so often and that’s adding to the amount of radio noise in the air at the event and no, the FMS should really not be running a honeypot… it can barely manage the field.

First night of all our events I walk around with a hot glue gun asking teams if I can help them with some basic goof proofing. I always ask politely and ask multiple times and have yet to have a team decline a radio check for glued barrel jacks or swapping to POE.

When going around just be extremely courteous.

Other checks - Rio power connections, VRM power etc. Hot glue fixes a lot of things.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Akash_Rastogi:

Other checks - Rio power connections, VRM power etc. Hot glue fixes a lot of things.

Bring some spare ferrules and a ferrule crimper if you have them. Many teams will just twist the wire and insert/strip too much into the Weidmullers. The exposed wire can touch, short or be too loose and disconnect the VRM , PCM or Rio from the PDP .

Ferrules will last longer are pretty cheap and once you show a team how to use it they usually will swap everything over to them the next season
Yep it’s in our “fix it” kit.

posts.name: Trevor G.
posts.cooked:
I’ve found that redundant power on the radio helps a lot.  The PoE injector and the barrel jack connector can both be wired to the 12V/2A slot on the VRM.

We also add a tiny bit of hot glue to the barrel jack after we get the radio imaged at competitions.

posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked:
This works if you are using the CTRE VRM but if your using the 18v Rev POE module there is no 18v tap for you to use to plug into the Barrel jack.

I have seen and heard of teams using the 18v POE and a 12v2a Barrel jack but can not recommend. It seems that internally there could be some  problems in the radio power circuit.
well then… this is interesting. I am now even more glad I’ve got our radio double powered. I’ll remember to go mount our radio better too.
You know dry wood attenuates wifi signals a lot less then all the metal most bots have. I think this is just another argument for more wood frame robots like ours

posts.name: TimO
posts.cooked: Thanks for confirming what my explanation to the parent! Honeypot was tongue firmly in cheek and still shows the tooth marks.

posts.name: D_Price (1708 Co-Lead Mentor)
posts.cooked: This is pure art and I am here for it. This seems to be the main case year in and year out. You nailed every single point from the Question (no answer) box to the fact that students and mentors alike still use their wifi hotspots even when instructed not to. I was guilty of this when I was a wee lad.

posts.name: Justin Tervay
posts.cooked:
marshall:

There is a set of ambient field radio conditions, in which one robot in a match can lose its radio link and then all other robots on the field will also lose their links and stop/stutter/disconnect/reconnect. It’s real.

Have you checked your firewall and updated your wifi drivers?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
marshall:

What I think is happening… and I’m just now digging into the weeds on 5Ghz AC wifi is that one of the clients (a robot) is dropping off and the field Access Point (the field wifi network) is then shuffling the clients around under a new set of conditions to form “optimal” links.

I think you’re on the right track.  I believe we’re actually running N, not AC.  When a client drops, the AP will stop receiving ack’s and will try to retransmit at lower and lower modulation rates (it’s going to assume that the client is not responding due to increased attenuation).  Since all clients operate on one channel, that’s also going to drop available airtime for other clients.  I think the other clients will stay at the same modulation rate they were at, but they’ll have significantly less airtime to work with until the AP realizes the one client is completely gone and stops trying to retransmit to it.  If the AP drops the rates of all clients down, that’s even worse!  I’m not sure what settings the AP exposes for tuning rate adaptation behavior, but I assume FIRST has looked into what’s available to tune.

So yes, one robot going offline or with poor radio placement will decrease the airtime available for other robots to get their data through.

posts.name: marshall
posts.cooked:
jtrv:

Have you checked your firewall and updated your wifi drivers?

I know man… I know.

What’s even more infuriating about this is that the DS seems to just blast packets out in a queue so as the drivers (high school students) are frantically pushing buttons and sticks to extremes, the robot isn’t doing anything and then boom… suddenly it is.  It just forcefully re-enables the robot and sends all of the queued items…

I’d love to have the DS go to a mode where it disconnects and forces us to manually re-enable but… I literally can’t even figure out how to suggest that as an option to be taken seriously.

posts.name: Bri
posts.cooked: We switched to double powering our radio after the horrible field connectivity issues we faced during Carson 2017. Am a big fan. We’re still using the old CTRE electronics system, but I really hope that the new REV system also has this capability.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
marshall:

What’s even more infuriating about this is that the DS seems to just blast packets out in a queue so as the drivers (high school students) are frantically pushing buttons and sticks to extremes, the robot isn’t doing anything and then boom… suddenly it is. It just forcefully re-enables the robot and sends all of the queued items…

The DS is sending UDP packets.  The network is doing some level of queuing and retransmits (yes, even UDP packets get retransmitted on wifi links).  We previously discussed potential causes and solutions re spikes in control latency here: Severe (>100%?) packet loss - #139 by Peter_Johnson
